questions.text: A 72 year old male patient presented with complaints of fatigability and chronic lower back pain. lab findings are given below: Hb- 9 g/dl; S. Ca- 11.5 mg/dl; serum M protein- 50g/l Which of the following lineage of cells is affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C The patient with fatigability and chronic lower back ache has anemia, hypercalcemia, and serum M protein raised. The most probable diagnosis will be plasma cell disorder. The involved cells will be plasma cells which are shown in image C.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Image shows macrophages The image shows neutrophils. The image shows eosinophils.

Extraedge:

Plasma Cells are polyclonal( produce either IgM or IgA with both kappa and lambda. When plasma cells become monoclonal (Producing either Kappa or Lambda )-Plasma cell dyscrasias

questions.text: "You were attending a ward round where your consultant was also talking about the different types of plasma cell disorders as he came across one patient with the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Arrange the given below plasma cell disorder in the ascending order of % of bone marrow plasma cells. 1. Smouldering MM 2. MGUS 3.Multiple myeloma. Select the correct answer from given below code"
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2<1<3 In the given question, on the basis of % of plasma cells found in bone marrow, we can arrange them as- MGUS- < 10% of plasma cells in BM. smouldering MM- >= 10% cells in BM. multiple myeloma- >= 60 % plasma cells in BM. Hence, the correct order will be option D. 2< 1< 3. Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS)-- Serum monoclonal protein (non-IgM type) <30 g/L Clonal bone marrow plasma cells <10% Absence of myeloma-defining events or amyloidosis that can be attributed to the plasma cell proliferative disorder. Smouldering Multiple Myeloma (Asymptomatic Myeloma)-- Both criteria must be met: Serum monoclonal protein (IgG or IgA) ≥30 g/L or urinary monoclonal protein ≥500 mg per 24 h and/or clonal bone marrow plasma cells 10–60% Absence of myeloma-defining events or amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presented with pain in the bone and weakness. He was subjected to blood investigation which showed- Hb- 9.1 g/dl; s.ca- 11 mg/dl; S.cr-2.1 mg/dl. Which of the following features described above are not a part of CRAB features found in MM?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above. In the given clinical scenario, the patient with the given clinical symptoms and lab investigation fits into the CRAB criteria of the MM. C- Hypercalcemia as S. ca- 11 mg/dl R- Renal failure as S. cr- 2.1 mg/dl. A-Anemia as Hb- 9 g/dl. B- bone pain Hence all the above options are part of CRAB features. Hence the best answer for this question will be option D

Extraedge:

The diagnostic criteria for multiple myeloma were updated by IMWG(International myeloma working group)Bone marrow plasma cells >=10% plus one of the following 7 features.

questions.text: You were reading about different types of plasma cell disorders during your final year. which of the following option denoted the sequence in which the plasma cell disorders progress?

options.label: B
options.text: Plasma cell leukemia ->MGUS-> Smouldering MM -> MM.

options.label: C
options.text: MGUS -> Smouldering MM ->Plasma cell leukemia-> MM.

options.label: D
options.text: MGUS -> Smouldering MM -> MM. -> Plasma cell leukemia

questions.correct_answer: D. MGUS -> Smouldering MM -> MM. -> Plasma cell leukemia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MGUS -> Smouldering MM -> MM. -> Plasma cell leukemia During the development of plasma cell disorders, first, the normal plasma cells with chromosomal instability will undergo clonal proliferation due to the effects of infection and inflammation. First, they develop into MGUS which is asymptomatic and progresses to a smouldering type of MM out of which very few develop into Multiple myeloma (MM) . Further multiple myeloma can develop into plasma cell leukemia. hence the answer to this question will be option D.

BM showing <10% of plasma cells. In the given question as asked, the BM biopsy finding in the case of MGUS will be <10% of plasma cells.

questions.text: A 64 year old male presented with bone pains in OPD. His previous reports suggested S. calcium was raised, hb- 8.9 g/dl and RFT was also deranged. His Skull X-ray was done which showed the following findings. Which of the following markers are increased which results in bony lesions in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above. In the given question, the patient has symptoms like bone pain, weakness . Along with that, the x-ray shows multiple lytic lesions. Lab investigation shows anemia, hypercalcemia and deranged RFT. The skull demonstrates the typical “punched out” lesions characteristic of MM. So the diagnosis for this patient is suggestive of multiple myeloma. In these patients, lytic lesions are formed due to elevated IL-6, IL-3 and MIP 1 alpha which directly increases the action of osteoclasts. Also, DKK-1 inhibits osteoblast differentiation which also plays a role in this So the correct answer to this question will be option D.
